unnormalised: Under Section 80G of the Income Tax Act, donations made to registered charitable institutions and trusts can be claimed as deductions from your taxable income. But here's the catch - not all donations qualify. To be eligible, the recipient organization must be registered under Section 12A of the Income Tax Act. Donations to political parties are explicitly excluded. So, that ₹500 you donated to your local political rally won't get you any tax benefits.

unnormalised: Now, let's talk about the deduction amount. Depending on the recipient organization, you can claim either 50% or 100% of the donation amount as a deduction. For instance, donations to certain government-approved institutions like the National Defence Fund or the Prime Minister's National Relief Fund qualify for a 100% deduction. On the other hand, donations to many other charitable trusts are eligible for only a 50% deduction. There's also a limit - the total deduction under Section 80G cannot exceed 10% of your adjusted gross total income. Let's say your gross income is ₹10,00,000 and you donate ₹2,00,000 to a trust eligible for a 50% deduction. You can only claim ₹50,000 as a deduction (10% of ₹10,00,000), not ₹1,00,000 (50% of ₹2,00,000), even if the recipient organization is registered under Section 12A.
